SENT.plain: The effects of antireflux surgery on Barrett's oesophagus were studied

Fifty-six patients (45 men and 11 women of median age 48.5 (range 20-78) years) with histologically confirmed Barrett's oesophagus (greater than 3 cm in length) and gastro-oesophageal reflux underwent antireflux surgery
Symptoms were noted and patients underwent manometry and pH recording before and after operation, and annual flexible endoscopy

Fundoplication resulted in a significant improvement in lower oesophageal sphincter pressure (median (interquartile range (i.q.r.)) 8 (5-14) mmHg before operation versus 17 (11-22) mmHg after operation, P < 0.001)

Twenty-four of the 56 patients had partial or complete regression of Barrett's oesophagus (median (i.q.r.) length 8 (3-18) cm before versus 4 (0-10) cm after operation, P < 0.001) but nine showed progression (median (i.q.r.) length 6 (3-11) cm before versus 10 (6-15) cm after operation, P < 0.01) (median follow-up 5.5 (range 2.0-10.5) years)
The length of Barrett's oesophagus was unchanged in 23 patients

Regression was more likely to occur in patients who underwent fundoplication with previous or concomitant vagotomy (chi 2 = 7.21, 1 d.f., P < 0.01) and in those with a good symptomatic result (chi 2 = 23.52, 1 d.f., P < 0.001)
